sections.content:
## warm-up

Welcome to Ukraine! Or rather, welcome to the **Ukrainian language**.

You might be looking at Ukrainian text and thinking, *"It looks like Russian,"* or *"It looks like a secret code."*

Let's address the first point immediately.

> üí° **Did You Know?**
>
> The Cyrillic alphabet was **NOT** invented by Russians! It was created in the 9th century in the First Bulgarian Empire by disciples of Saints Cyril and Methodius. While Ukrainian and Russian share an alphabet, they are distinct languages‚Äîlike English and Dutch. Ukrainian has unique letters (like **–á** and **“ê**) that give it a melodic, Italian-like sound.

Now, about that "secret code." It‚Äôs much easier to crack than you think. By the end of this module, you will be able to read actual Ukrainian words like **–º–µ—Ç—Ä–æ**, **—Ä–µ—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–∞–Ω**, **–ø–∞—Å–ø–æ—Ä—Ç**, and **–∑–µ–±—Ä–∞**.

## presentation

### Group 1: The True Friends
These letters are your safe zone. They look like English and sound (mostly) like English.

| Ukrainian | Sound (IPA) | English Approx | Example |
|-----------|-------------|----------------|---------|
| **–ê –∞**   | /…ë/         | f**a**ther     | **–ê**–Ω—Ç–æ–Ω |
| **–ï –µ**   | /…õ/         | b**e**d        | **–ï**—Ä–∞ |
| **–Ü —ñ**   | /i/         | mach**i**ne    | **–Ü**–¥–µ—è |
| **–û –æ**   | /…î/         | m**o**re       | **–û**–ø–µ—Ä–∞ |
| **–ö –∫**   | /k/         | **s**kill      | **–ö**–∞–≤–∞ |
| **–ú –º**   | /m/         | **m**ap        | **–ú**–∞–º–∞ |
| **–¢ —Ç**   | /t/         | **t**op        | **–¢**–∞—Ç–æ |

> ‚ö° **Pro Tip**
>
> In Ukrainian, vowels are **pure**. **O** is never a diphthong like in "G**o**". It's always open and round like in "P**o**rt".

Let's read some words using only these letters. Listen closely to the audio.
*   **–¢–ê–¢–û** [üîä](audio_tato) (Dad)
*   **–ú–ê–ú–ê** [üîä](audio_mama) (Mom)
*   **–¢–û–ú** [üîä](audio_tom) (Tom)
*   **–ö–û–¢** [üîä](audio_kot) (Code/Cat depending on language - wait, Cat is –ö–Ü–¢ in Ukrainian!)
*   **–ê–¢–û–ú** [üîä](audio_atom) (Atom)
*   **–¢–ê–ö–¢** [üîä](audio_takt) (Tact)

### Group 2: The False Friends (The Traitors)
These are the tricksters. They look familiar, but they will betray you if you trust them.

| Letter | Looks Like | Sounds Like | IPA | Memory Hook |
|--------|------------|-------------|-----|-------------|
| **–í –≤** | B | **V** | /v/ | **V**ery Good **B**eer |
| **–ù –Ω** | H | **N** | /n/ | **N**ot an **H**! |
| **–† —Ä** | P | **R** | /r/ | **R**olling **P** |
| **–° —Å** | C | **S** | /s/ | **S**nake **C**urve |
| **–£ —É** | y | **U** (oo) | /u/ | **U** look like **y**ou? |
| **–• —Ö** | X | **Kh** (h) | /x/ | Lo**ch** Ness |

Let's try to decipher these.
*   **–í** looks like B, but it vibrates: **–í** (Vvvv).
*   **–ù** looks like H, but it says No: **–ù** (Nnnn).
*   **–†** looks like P, but it roars: **–†** (Rrrr).
*   **–°** looks like C, but it hisses: **–°** (Ssss).
*   **–•** is the sound you make when clearing your throat, like in "Lo**ch**".

**Read these carefully:**
*   **–°–£–ü** [üîä](audio_sup) (Soup) - Not "cyn"!
*   **–†–ï–°–¢–û–†–ê–ù** [üîä](audio_restoran) (Restaurant) - Not "pectopah"!
*   **–ú–ï–¢–†–û** [üîä](audio_metro) (Metro) - Not "metpo"!
*   **–•–ê–û–°** [üîä](audio_khaos) (Chaos)
*   **–ù–ï–¢** [üîä](audio_net) (Net/Internet)

> üé¨ **Pop Culture Moment**
>
> Hollywood often mixes Cyrillic letters into English text to look "Russian", writing things like **"H–£–òT F–û–Ø –Ø–ïD O–°TO–ëE–Ø"**. To a Ukrainian, this looks like gibberish. Don't fall for "Faux Cyrillic"!

### Group 3: The New Friends (The Strangers)
These are completely new symbols.

| Letter | Sound | IPA | Similar English | Shape |
|--------|-------|-----|-----------------|-------|
| **–ë –±** | **B** | /b/ | **B**oy | Looks like a **b** with a flat top. |
| **–î –¥** | **D** | /d/ | **D**og | Looks like a **D** with legs. |
| **–ó –∑** | **Z** | /z/ | **Z**oo | Looks like the number **3**. |
| **–õ –ª** | **L** | /l/ | **L**amp | Like an upside-down **V**. |
| **–ü –ø** | **P** | /p/ | **P**ark | Mathematical Pi ($\pi$). Use it for **P**ark. |
| **–§ —Ñ** | **F** | /f/ | **F**arm | A circle with a line through it. |

**International Words (Cognates):**
*   **–ë–ê–ù–ö** [üîä](audio_bank) (Bank)
*   **–ü–ê–†–ö** [üîä](audio_park) (Park)
*   **–ö–ê–§–ï** [üîä](audio_cafe) (Cafe) - Wait, **–§** is F!
*   **–¢–ê–ö–°–Ü** [üîä](audio_taksi) (Taxi)
*   **–†–ê–î–Ü–û** [üîä](audio_radio) (Radio)
*   **–§–£–¢–ë–û–õ** [üîä](audio_futbol) (Football)
*   **–°–¢–£–î–ï–ù–¢** [üîä](audio_student) (Student)

## narrative: The Arrival

Tom arrives in Kyiv. He is a **–¢–£–†–ò–°–¢** [üîä](audio_turist). He does not speak Ukrainian yet, but he has the "Cyrillic Code".

He steps out of the plane. He needs his documents. He finds his **–ü–ê–°–ü–û–†–¢** [üîä](audio_pasport). Inside, he sees his **–í–Ü–ó–ê** [üîä](audio_viza). Everything is okay.

He walks to Customs. The officer asks for documents.
**–û—Ñ—ñ—Ü–µ—Ä:** –ü–∞—Å–ø–æ—Ä—Ç?
**–¢–æ–º:** –¢–∞–∫, –ø–∞—Å–ø–æ—Ä—Ç.
**–û—Ñ—ñ—Ü–µ—Ä:** –í—ñ–∑–∞?
**–¢–æ–º:** –¢–∞–∫, –≤—ñ–∑–∞.

Tom walks out. He needs to go to the city. He looks for a **–¢–ê–ö–°–Ü** [üîä](audio_taksi), but it is expensive. He sees a sign: **–ú–ï–¢–†–û** [üîä](audio_metro). Perfect.

In the metro, he looks at a map (**–ö–ê–†–¢–ê** [üîä](audio_karta)). He sees many stations. He goes to the center.

On the street, he is hungry. He sees a huge sign: **–†–ï–°–¢–û–†–ê–ù** [üîä](audio_restoran). No, too expensive. He sees a small sign: **–ö–ê–§–ï** [üîä](audio_cafe). He goes inside.
He sees the menu.
1. **–°–£–ü** [üîä](audio_sup)
2. **–°–ê–õ–ê–¢** [üîä](audio_salat)
3. **–ü–Ü–¶–ê** [üîä](audio_pitsa)
4. **–ö–ê–í–ê** [üîä](audio_kava)

He smiles. He understands everything. He orders **–ü–Ü–¶–ê** and **–ö–ê–í–ê**. The waiter asks: "**–û–ö?**". Tom says: "**–¢–ê–ö!**" (Yes).

Later, Tom calls his **–ú–ê–ú–ê** [üîä](audio_mama) and **–¢–ê–¢–û** [üîä](audio_tato). "Phone" in Ukrainian is **–¢–ï–õ–ï–§–û–ù** [üîä](audio_telefon). He tells them: "Kyiv is beautiful. And I can read!"

## cultural insight

### The Sound of Ukrainian
Ukrainian is often called "The Nightingale Language" (*—Å–æ–ª–æ–≤'—ó–Ω–∞ –º–æ–≤–∞*) because of its musicality. Unlike English, which often swallows vowels, Ukrainian vowels are crisp, clear, and open.

When you say **–û–ü–ï–†–ê** [üîä](audio_opera), don't say "Op-rah". Say "O-PE-RA". Every letter counts.

> üí° **Did You Know?**
>
> While Russian is stressed and rhythmic in a hard way, Ukrainian flows more melodically. This is mostly due to syllable structure. When you speak Ukrainian, try to "sing" a little bit.

Let's look at a map of a Ukrainian city center. You can already read the signs!
1.  **–ë–ê–†** [üîä](audio_bar)
2.  **–†–ï–°–¢–û–†–ê–ù** [üîä](audio_restoran)
3.  **–ë–ê–ù–ö** [üîä](audio_bank)
4.  **–ú–ï–¢–†–û** [üîä](audio_metro)
5.  **–ü–ê–†–ö** [üîä](audio_park)
6.  **–¢–ï–ê–¢–†** [üîä](audio_teatr) (Theater)

You are no longer blind to the letters. You are deciphering the code.

### The City Sounds
As you walk through the streets, notice how the sounds of the city match the letters you just learned. The **–ú–ï–¢–†–û** rumbles. The **–ö–ê–§–ï** hisses with steam. The **–ü–ê–†–ö** is quiet.

> üé≠ **Folklore/Traditions Corner**
>
> In Ukrainian folklore, words have power. We don't just speak; we "sing" our thoughts. This dates back to the **Kobzars**, wandering bards who played the kobza and bandura. They preserved Ukrainian history through oral songs when writing was forbidden.

### Italic Warning
One last secret. In handwriting or italics, some letters change shape.
*   **—Ç** becomes *m* (looks like an English 'm')
*   **–¥** becomes *g* (looks like an English 'g')
*   **–∏** becomes *u* (looks like an English 'u')

Don't panic! We will practice this in Module 02. For now, focus on the Print forms.

## practice

Let's verify your decoding skills.

First, let's distinguish the sounds.
*   **–í** vs **–ë**: **–í**—ñ–∑–∞ [üîä](audio_viza) vs **–ë**–∞—Ä [üîä](audio_bar).
*   **–°** vs **–ö**: **–°**—É–ø [üîä](audio_sup) vs **–ö**–∞–≤–∞ [üîä](audio_kava).
*   **–†** vs **–ü**: **–†**–µ—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–∞–Ω [üîä](audio_restoran) vs **–ü**–∞—Ä–∫ [üîä](audio_park).

**Rhythm Practice:**
Read these aloud. Keep the rhythm steady.
*   –ú–∞–º–∞, —Ç–∞—Ç–æ, –¥—ñ–º. (Mom, dad, home.)
*   –ë–∞–Ω–∫, –ø–∞—Ä–∫, –∫–∞—Ñ–µ. (Bank, park, cafe.)
*   –ü—ñ—Ü–∞, —Å—É–ø, —Å–∞–ª–∞—Ç. (Pizza, soup, salad.)

Now, imagine you are a **–¢–£–†–ò–°–¢** in Kyiv. You have your **–ü–ê–°–ü–û–†–¢** and your **–í–Ü–ó–ê**. You want to check your **–Ü–ù–¢–ï–†–ù–ï–¢** [üîä](audio_internet). You see a sign: **–ó–û–ù–ê WI-FI**. (Zone Wi-Fi). You are safe!

---

sections.name: –ü—ñ–¥—Å—É–º–æ–∫
sections.content:
Congratulations! You have just unlocked the first layer of the Cyrillic code.

You now know:
*   The **True Friends** (A, E, I, O, K, M, T) that are easy.
*   The **False Friends** (–í, –ù, –†, –°, –£, –•) that trick you.
*   The **New Friends** (–ë, –î, –ó, –õ, –ü, –§) that are unique.

You can already read words like **–º–µ—Ç—Ä–æ**, **—Ä–µ—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–∞–Ω**, **–±–∞–Ω–∫**, and **—Ç–∞–∫—Å—ñ**. You are not just looking at strange symbols anymore; you are reading a European language spoken by over 40 million people.

In the next module, we will learn the slightly weirder letters‚Äîthe ones that look like tridents, beetles, and forks. See you there!

## true-false: Alphabet Facts
> Read and decide if true or false.

- [x] The letter **–í** sounds like English **V**.
  > Correct! It vibrates like **V** in Victory.

- [ ] The letter **–†** sounds like English **P**.
  > Incorrect! **–†** sounds like a rolled **R**. **–ü** sounds like **P**.

- [x] The letter **–•** makes a sound like in "Lo**ch**".
  > Correct! It is a velar fricative.

- [ ] Ukrainian vowels are often silent.
  > Incorrect! Ukrainian vowels are full and pure.

- [x] The word **–ú–ï–¢–†–û** is neuter.
  > Correct! It ends in **-–û**.

- [ ] **–†–ï–°–¢–û–†–ê–ù** sounds like "Pectopah".
  > Incorrect! It sounds like "Restoran". P is R, C is S, H is N.

- [x] **–ö–Ü–¢** means Cat.
  > Correct! It uses the unique letter **–Ü**.

- [ ] The letter **–ù** sounds like English **H**.
  > Incorrect! **–ù** sounds like **N**.

- [x] **–§** sounds like **F**.
  > Correct!

- [ ] **–£** sounds like **Y**.
  > Incorrect! **–£** sounds like **U** (moon).

- [x] **–õ** looks like an upside-down V.
  > Correct! It is Lambda.

- [ ] **–°** sounds like **K**.
  > Incorrect! **–°** is always **S**.

# Summary

Congratulations! You have just unlocked the first layer of the Cyrillic code.

You now know:
*   The **True Friends** (A, E, I, O, K, M, T) that are easy.
*   The **False Friends** (–í, –ù, –†, –°, –£, –•) that trick you.
*   The **New Friends** (–ë, –î, –ó, –õ, –ü, –§) that are unique.

You can already read words like **–º–µ—Ç—Ä–æ**, **—Ä–µ—Å—Ç–æ—Ä–∞–Ω**, **–±–∞–Ω–∫**, and **—Ç–∞–∫—Å—ñ**. You are not just looking at strange symbols anymore; you are reading a European language spoken by over 40 million people.

In the next module, we will learn the slightly weirder letters‚Äîthe ones that look like tridents, beetles, and forks. See you there!
